Award.AwardTitle: IGERT Plant System Biology Interdisciplinary Graduate Training Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: With the completion of plant genome sequences and with numerous large data sets emerging, an essential need has arisen to train students in plant systems biology at the interface of computational genomics, systems modeling and plant sciences. This entirely new interdisciplinary program will provide a unique training environment for graduate students and will position them at the frontier of systems biology to address major challenges facing plant scientists and agricultural biotechnology. The program will include focused mentoring of each student in two labs by two advisors from distinct disciplines. An entirely new curriculum, made possible through new faculty recruitment, will train students in post genomic plant sciences, proteomics, systems biology and network modeling and will include rigorous professional career preparation. A dynamic outreach program will assist in the recruitment of underrepresented students. Industry internships will draw upon the local active biotechnology arena. There are several broader impacts of this project. Interdisciplinary training in plant systems biology will stimulate innovations in the nation's agricultural and biotechnology industries, address global needs to feed the growing population and contribute to reducing environmental impacts of agriculture. Fresh water and food shortages are predicted to grow substantially in the coming decades. Plant biotechnology and molecular breeding will provide powerful contributions toward solving these problems. This comprehensive educational program will train graduate students at the interface of systems modeling and plant sciences and will have far-reaching impacts by producing highly trained scientists who will emerge as leaders in fields arising from the revolution in genomics information. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IGERT training grant funded interdisciplinary plant systems biology graduate training at the University of California San Diego and at the neighboring Salk Institute. Our institutions have made major contributions to the fields of Plant Biology, Systems Biology and Computational Research, but an integration of these disciplines into a coordinated training program posed an unmet challenge. This interdisciplinary training program trained students with different backgrounds at the interface of systems modeling, computational genomics and plant sciences and positioned our Ph.D. students at the frontier of plant systems biology. The program included focused mentoring of each student in two laboratories by two advisors from distinct disciplines. The graduate curriculum, made possible through new faculty recruitments and development of innovative graduate graduate training, provided in depth expertise to students in fields including computational genomics, proteomics, modeling and molecular plant sciences. Our professional preparation program prepared students for emerging industry and academic career requirements through courses and practical experience in speaking, ethics, biotechnology business issues and academic career preparation.

The interdisciplinary plant systems biology training and research of our graduate students produced professionals with outstanding records of achievement leading to diverse accelerated careers in biotechnology, industry and academia. The results of research also provide a foundation towards developing new avenues for addressing global needs of agriculture to feed the growing global population, while greatly reducing the environmentally detrimental impacts of conventional agriculture. Fresh water and food shortages and loss of natural forests to agriculture are predicted to grow substantially worldwide in the next decades. These problems will increasingly contribute to environmental problems, instability and hunger in regions of the world. Genomics-assisted plant biotechnology and precision molecular breeding provide promising and empowering contributions to solutions of these problems. Within our outreach program, our graduate students gained experience in inspiring school and undergraduate interns, in presenting plant research and environmental aspects and policy issues in agriculture.

Our IGERT training program provided an unmet need to train graduate students at the interface of systems level biology & genomics and plant biology. This program has had far-reaching impacts by producing highly trained students who took advantage of new career opportunities and are now the leaders in fields arising from the revolution in genomics information. This program has substantially impacted how graduate will be trained in the future across many disciplines at UCSD.

Our IGERT students have accomplished truly outstanding research advances. This is clearly documented by the publications of IGERT students, which include over 50 publications, with many publications in leading international journals, including Nature, Science, Cell, PNAS, Elife (http://labs.biology.ucsd.edu/psbigert/igertstudentpublications). These publiactions reported major advances in a systems biological understanding of plants, or led to development of novel systems biological tools that are widely used today. Our IGERT students' research publications are very well cited and the career success of our presently graduated IGERT students is a testament to their innovative research advances. These Outcomes would not have been possible without the IGERT support.
